title-group.article-title: Mortality risk factors in chest trauma patients in a level one trauma center in southern Iran

contrib-group.aff: 1https://ror.org/01n3s4692grid.412571.40000 0000 8819 4698 Trauma Research Center, Shiraz University of Medical Sciences, Shiraz, Iran
2https://ror.org/028qtbk54grid.412573.60000 0001 0745 1259Health Human Resources Research Center, School of Health Management and Information Sciences, Shiraz University, Shiraz, Iran

abstract.p: Chest trauma is one of the most prevalent subgroups of trauma, accounting for 1 out of 4 deaths relating to trauma. Gaining insights into the trends of chest trauma is crucial in tackling its significant role in causing injuries and fatalities, particularly in low- and middle-income nations. Therefore, we aimed to investigate the prevalence of chest trauma, the types of injuries, mechanisms of injury, and predictors of mortality in the largest level one trauma center in southern Iran. This retrospective study included 4257 patients who were admitted to a tertiary medical center in southern Iran with chest trauma as the primary diagnosis from March 2019 to March 2022. All patients were divided into survived (n = 3505) and deceased (n = 752) groups. Data were analyzed by IBM SPSS statistics version 26, using independent samples t-test, Chi-Square test, and multivariate logistic regression. The mean age was 37 ± 16.1 and 50.15 ± 21.5 in survived group and deceased group, respectively. Most of the population were men in both groups. The mean of the injury severity score (ISS) was higher in the deceased group (37.22 ± 25.32) than in the survived group (15 ± 10.4). All on-arrival vital signs show significant differences between the two groups. Among various types of thoracic injuries, pneumothorax (OR 2.04, CI 1.52–2.73, P = 0.001) and rib fracture (OR 1.34, CI 1.00–1.79, P = 0.04) increases the odds of mortality. Multivariate logistic regression analysis showed that age, gender, ISS, types of thoracic injury, and some on-arrival vital signs are proper mortality predictors in patients with chest wall injury. Multiple risk factors including age, gender, ISS, type of injury, and on-arrival vital signs have been indicated for predicting mortality in chest trauma patients. Proper care and immediate management of these risk factors could lower the mortality morbidity among these patients.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Chest trauma is a significant public health problem that accounts for a substantial proportion of all trauma admissions and deaths1. Globally, chest trauma accounts for 10–15 percent of all traumas and is the second most common traumatic injury in non-intentional trauma2–4. Furthermore, chest trauma directly constitutes nearly 25% of trauma-related deaths2,5 and is the third most common cause of death after abdominal injury and head trauma in polytrauma patients, as the chest houses vital organs such as the heart, lungs, and major blood vessels6,7.

Chest trauma has a high mortality rate, ranging from 6.6 to 60%1,4,8,9. The mortality rate is variable among different authors and studies, but it is particularly burdensome in low- and middle-income countries1,4,8–10. Chest trauma, apart from being a primary cause of death, is associated with chronic pain, mental distress, chest wall deformities, reduced quality of life, and temporary or permanent disability11,12. Studies show that in average, it takes 19 days for patients with to return to work after rib fracture13. Additionally, it imposes substantial costs on healthcare systems, particularly trauma and acute care facilities5. Blunt chest injuries are more common than penetrating injuries, and the most common causes include motor vehicle accidents, falls, crush injuries, and occupational accidents6,14.

Over 70 percent of chest injuries are related to road traffic accidents3. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), approximately 1.35 million people lose their lives in road traffic accidents each year and 20–50 million people are injured. This is particularly significant considering that 93 percent of these fatalities occur on the roads of low- and middle-income countries7. Chest trauma encompasses various types of injuries, including rib contusions, rib fractures, lung contusions, hemothorax, pneumothorax, flail chest, and ruptured bronchi3,15.

Predictors of outcomes and mortality following chest trauma vary widely in different studies16. Rib fractures occur in approximately 40% of patients with chest trauma. Multiple rib fractures are strongly associated with pneumothorax, hemothorax, and pulmonary injuries, which can lead to higher mortality rates17. Flail chest occurs when three or more adjacent ribs are fractured in at least two places. Although this is a relatively rare injury, it is a predictor of poor outcomes in patients with chest trauma11. Additionally, severe lung contusion, higher injury severity score (ISS) and thoracic abbreviated injury scale (AIS), older age, rib fractures, multiple injuries, length of hospital stay, and comorbidities were identified as risk factors for mortality in chest trauma5,6,11,18. Early diagnosis and treatment of chest trauma are crucial and can prevent mortality18,19. Treatment goals include rational fluid management, supportive oxygen therapy, mechanical ventilation, chest tube placement, thoracostomy tube, surgical interventions, optimal pain control, and physiotherapy6,19,20.

The etiological pattern, outcomes, and mortality of chest trauma vary significantly from one country to another and even within a single country due to environmental, social, economic, and political factors2,20. Furthermore, most trauma-related deaths are preventable, and early recognition of patterns and risk factors reduces the injuries resulting from chest trauma3,5. Based on the mentioned cases and the importance of identifying accurate predictive parameters for chest trauma, and considering the limited research conducted on this issue in Iran, this study aimed to investigate the prevalence of chest trauma, the types of injuries, mechanisms of injury, and predictors of mortality in the largest level one trauma center in southern Iran.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: This was a retrospective cross-sectional study conducted over a three-year period at tertiary Trauma Hospital southern Iran. The study population included all patients with chest trauma who were admitted to this center from March 21, 2019, to March 20, 2022. Inclusion criteria were having one of the types of chest trauma, being 18 years of age or older, and the exclusion criteria were trauma patients under follow-up, chest trauma accompanied by burns or poisoning, incomplete recorded data, and not having vital signs upon hospital admission. The patients were classified into two groups based on the designated AIS score: survivors and deceased, and the variables were compared between these two groups. Chest trauma was the most severe injury in all the patients based on their AIS severity score.

The data for this study were retrospectively extracted from patient records. The extracted data included demographic characteristics (age, gender), injury severity score, vital signs (systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, respiratory rate, pulse rate), type of chest injury (rib fracture, sternum fracture, clavicle fracture, scapula fracture, pneumothorax, hemothorax, hemopneumothorax, lung contusion, lung laceration, tracheal injury, traumatic aortic injury, intra-thoracic organs, thoracic spine injuries (including vertebral fracture, tear in spinal cord, rupture of ligaments, dislocation of vertebrae, and intervertebral disk damages), multiple injuries), injury mechanisms (vehicle or motorcycle accident, pedestrian accident, falls, assault, suicide attempt, and other mechanisms), and length of hospital stay. Since chest X-rays (radiography) often fall short in detecting most fractures and may potentially miss actual injuries, and considering that computed tomography (CT) offers a higher sensitivity for diagnosing fractures compared to radiography, along with the added advantage of evaluating intrathoracic injuries17, this study relied on CT reports for the diagnosis of various chest injuries.

Data were analyzed using SPSS software version 26. For quantitative variables, the data were reported as mean (standard deviation), median (interquartile range), and for categorical variables, as numbers (percentages). Comparisons between the groups were conducted using the Chi-square test for categorical variables and the independent t-test for quantitative variables. Logistic regression models were employed to predict mortality in various types of chest injuries. A p-value less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
This study consists of 4257 patients who were emergently admitted to a tertiary trauma center in southern Iran between 2019 and 2022 primarily diagnosed with chest wall injury. All patients were divided into two groups, the survived group, and the deceased group, containing 3505 (82.3%) and 752 (17.7%) patients, respectively. The demographic characteristics of all participants are shown in Table 1. The mean age of the survived group was 37 ± 16.1 years and the deceased group was 50.15 ± 21.5 years (P = 0.0001). In both groups, ages 18 to 45 had the highest frequency. The survived group consisted of 2962 (84.5%) male patients, while they were 607 (80.7%) in the deceased group (P = 0.01).Table 1
Demographic characteristics of all participants.

The mean injury severity score (ISS) shows a significant difference between two groups, which was 15 ± 10.4 in the survived group and 37.22 ± 25.32 in the deceased group (P = 0.0001). The most frequent ISS was 9–15 in the survived group (33.1% of patients) and > 24 in the deceased group (64.6% of the patients). All on-arrival vital signs were significantly different between both groups. The mean Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) of the survived group and the deceased group was 125.24 ± 22.34 mmHg and 119.73 ± 32.03 mmHg respectively (P = 0.0001). The mean Diastolic Blood Pressure (DBP) of the survived group and the deceased group was 78.9 mmHg ± 15.25 and 75.03 ± 20.13 mmHg respectively (P = 0.0001). The Pulse Rate (PR) was also significantly different with the mean of 97.92 ± 21.76 beat per minute in the survived group and 100.2 ± 28.74 (28.74) in the other group (P = 0.02). The Respiratory Rate (RR) had a mean of 19.05 ± 6.62 in the survived group and 20.21 ± 7.96 the deceased group (P = 0.001) (Table 2).Table 2

The prevalence of some types of thorax injury was meaningfully different between both groups, such as pneumothorax (P = 0.0001), hemothorax (P = 0.0001), lung laceration (P = 0.05), and thorax internal organ damage (P = 0.001). Car accidents (27.2%), motorcycle accidents (19.7%), and falling-down (15.2%) were frequent mechanisms of injury in the survived group, while pedestrian accidents (27.8%), car accidents (24.2%), and falling-down (20.2%) made up most mechanisms of action in the deceased group (P = 0.0001). The length of hospital stay was another variable that was statistically different between both groups. 1386 (39.5%) patients in the survived group stayed 8 to 30 days in the hospital, while 371 (49.3%) patients in the deceased group lasted less than 1 day in the hospital (P = 0.0001) (Table 2).

Based on logistic regression results (Table 3), rib fracture (OR 1.34; 95% CI 1.00–1.79), pneumothorax (OR 2.04; 95% CI 1.52–2.73), and hemothorax (OR 0.52; 95% CI 0.39–0.70) were significant prognostic mechanisms of thorax trauma among the patients (P < 0.05). A multivariate logistic regression was performed to determine the predictors of Mortality among Thorax injury. Every year a patient became older in the range of 46–66 years, the odds of mortality increased 10.12 times (95% CI 7.72–13.26), while in the patients who were older than 66 years old, the mortality odds ratio was 3.96 (95% CI 2.96–5.30) (P = 0.0001). The injury severity score (ISS) is another significant mortality predicting factor (Table 4). Among vital sign indexes, pulse rate was associated with 0.993 the odds of mortality (95% CI 0.989–0.997), while systolic blood pressure increases the odds of mortality by 1.010 times (95% CI 1.004–1.016) (P < 0.05).Table 3

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study indicates that deceased patients were older, had higher rates of pneumothorax and higher ISS, and pedestrian accident was the highest mechanism of injury among them; while survived individuals were younger, had higher rates of hemothorax, lung laceration, and damage to internal organs of thorax, and car accident were the highest mechanism of injury among them. Our study also showed that having pneumothorax or rib fracture, being older, having higher ISS than the reference range, and having lower on-arrival systolic blood pressure are significant predictors of mortality among chest trauma patients.

A study in 2021 have shown that the majority of chest trauma cases were attributed to road traffic accidents3, which was in line with our study. Blunt trauma was predominant in 95.3% of cases. Rib fractures and lung contusions had the highest prevalence among chest injuries. Studies also suggest that chest wall injuries, including rib fractures, account for the most common type of injury in blunt chest trauma21. On the other hand, lung contusion and multiple injury were the highest type of thorax injury in our study. Pneumothorax occurred in 55.5% of cases, and hemothorax in 33.8%, with the most common indication for emergency thoracotomy. Chest trauma is a significant public health concern, especially among young men, and road traffic accidents are the primary cause of chest trauma in Iran. Early recognition of patterns, etiology, and proper trauma management can reduce the incidence of chest trauma-related injuries3.

In a review study in 2021 in China, the average age of chest trauma patients was 50.2 years, with 79.4% of them being male7. Conversely, in our study patients were younger and higher percentage of males was observed. Higher rate of male drivers compared to female drivers in middle east could be the underlying reason for this difference, as a recent systematic review in conducted the middle east suggests that most of the burden caused by chest trauma is brought upon male patients in their second and third decade of life22. Associated injuries were present in half of the patients, with most of these being limb fractures. Road traffic accidents accounted for almost half of injuries, with the majority involving motor vehicles, which is similar in recent studies22. Compared to other mechanisms of chest trauma, road traffic-related chest injuries affected older men and women more, with a higher occurrence of rib fractures and sternum fractures, and higher injury severity scores (ISS).

Although vital signs of the patients on hospital arrival were statistically significant in predicting the mortality rate among them, the clinical significance of these findings remain questionable, as they fall into the normal measurement rages. This dilemma might be caused by our large study population24,25. Further prospective or metanalytic studies, in which the intervention would be different for patients with various vital signs measurements, are required to shed light on the true significance of these differences.

Surgery was required in most of chest trauma patients related to road traffic accidents, while most non-road traffic-related chest injuries were managed conservatively or with chest tube thoracostomy. Road traffic-related chest trauma resulted in longer hospital stays, higher ICU utilization, a higher rate of ventilator support, and higher mortality compared to non-road traffic-related chest injuries. Road traffic accidents continue to be the leading cause of chest injuries in Iran, predominantly affecting middle-aged men and often resulting in rib fractures with concurrent injuries occurring frequently in other body parts. It is reasonable to assume that the mechanism of motor vehicle crash, in which the wheel and windshield can be potentially hazardous during the accident, could be the underlying reason for this. Treatments mainly involve tube thoracostomy and surgical approaches7.

Chest trauma accounted for half of traumatic injuries in 2020 in a study conducted in Germany6. Higher ISS and AIS in the chest region were significantly associated with a higher mortality rate, which was similar to our results. Younger patients (less than 40 years old) were more often exposed to severe chest injuries but showed a lower mortality rate. Patients with severe lung contusions had more complications and a higher mortality rate. Severe lung contusion, higher ISS and thoracic AIS scores, and older age were significantly associated with higher mortality rates. Similarly, older age and higher ISS were significant predictors for mortality among chest trauma patients. Recent studies indicate that thoracic trauma can result in significant mortality and morbidity rates in patients older than 65 years of age23. Blunt chest trauma can be well managed with optimal pain control, chest tube insertion, and chest physiotherapy. Optimal management with improved survival rates is achievable in specialized centers with multidisciplinary teamwork and the presence of thoracic surgery expertise6.

In the study conducted in 2022, a total of 1120 adults and 1038 elderly patients who were hospitalized with blunt chest trauma on an emergency basis were examined5. The average age of adult patients and elderly patients was 46.6 and 78.9 years, respectively. Both elderly and adult patients showed a 1% mortality rate. Nevertheless, the overall mortality rate was 17.7% in our study; further retrospective studies are required to shed light on the risk-factors of geriatric mortality in trauma patients. In the aforementioned study, mortality was significantly associated with liver diseases, respiratory illnesses, trauma, burns, poisons, and presence of platelet/white blood cell diseases.

sec.title: Weakness and strengths
sec.p: This study was conducted in the largest, most advance trauma center in southern Iran during a 3-year period. A large number of patients were enrolled in the study and multiple risk factors were determined. Limitations of this study, due to retrospective nature of it, was the loss of some data in medical records of the patients. Further multi-analysis studies and possibly prospective cohort studies with a predefined protocol are required to precisely designate the risk factors of mortality and morbidity in patients with chest trauma and improve the overall care of such patients.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The findings show that in the deceased patients who were emergently admitted to the tertiary trauma center with chest trauma injury as the primary diagnosis, age, injury severity score (ISS), the specific mechanism of injury, and length of stay in the hospital were significantly different compared to the patients who were survived. Our study also indicates that pneumothorax and rib fracture as the mechanisms of thorax injury, higher age, having higher ISS than the reference range, and having lower on-arrival systolic blood pressure increase odds of mortality in traumatic patients. Proper care and immediate management of these risk factors could lower the mortality morbidity among these patients.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: MK: study conception and design, data acquisition, data analysis, drafting and revision. MY&NB&MRY: study conception and design, data interpretation, drafting and revision.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: The Shiraz University of Medical Science supported this study in the context of a dissertation project (Grant Number 27120).

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The datasets used and/or analyzed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
notes.p: This study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of the Shiraz University of Medical Sciences (Approval ID: IR.SUMS.MED.REC.1402.286). A statement to confirm that all methods were performed in accordance with the ethical standards as laid down in the Declaration of Helsinki and its later amendments or comparable ethical standards. A sentence confirming that written informed consent was obtained from all participants.
